div.l: By cause that the Cradill by it stood
And nyst where she was for it was derke
And faire and well she crepte in by the Clerke
And lieth full still and wolde haue caught a slepe
Within a while this Iohn this Clerke vp lepe
And on̄ this good wif he leide on̄ sore
So mery a fitte had she not full yore
He prickith harde and depe as he were madde
This Ioly lyf haue thise Clerkys hladdehaddeladde
That till the Cokke thrise be gan̄ to synge
Aleyn̄ wex wery in the mornynge
For he had swonkyn̄ all the longe nyght
And saide farewell Malkyn̄ swete wyght
The day is com̄ y may no lenger abide
But eủermore where so eủere y go or ride
I am̄ thyn̄ owne Clerke so haue y helle
Nowe dere lemman̄ qduod she go fare welle
But or thou go othyng y will the telle
When̄ that thou wendyst homward by the Melle
Right at the entre of the dore behynde
Thou shalte a Cake of half a busshell fynde
That was made of youre owne mele
Which that I halpe my fader for to stele
And good lemman̄ god the save and kepe
And with that worde almoste she began̄ to wepe
Aleyn̄ vp̄ arist and thought er it dawe
I will go crepe in by my felawe
And founde the Cradell at his honde anon̄
By god qduod he all wronge haue y gon̄
Myn̄ hede is toty of my swynke to nyght
That makith me that y go not aright
I wote well by the Cradill y haue mysgo
Here lieth the Millere and his wif also
And furth he goith on̄ · xxᵗⁱ · devilway
Vnto the bed there as the Millere lay
He wende haue cropyn̄ by his felawe Iohn
And by the Millere yn he crepith anon̄
And caught hym̄ by the necke and softe spake
And seide thou Iohn · thou Swyneshed awake
For cristis soule · and here a noble game
For by that lorde that is clepid is is seynte Iame
I haue · thrise in this shorte nyght
Swyfed the Millers doughtᵘur bolte vpright
